verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: This introductory phrase, common in Leviticus, emphasizes God as the direct source of revelation and law—a reminder of His authority and the seriousness of the priesthood.

verses.text: "Take Aaron and his sons with him, the garments, the anointing oil, a bull for the sin offering, two rams, and a basket of unleavened bread."
verses.comment: The ordination materials are listed, highlighting each element's symbolic importance—especially the anointing oil, which spiritually foreshadows the consecration of leaders who mediate between God and people.

verses.text: "And assemble all the congregation at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting."
verses.comment: The public nature of the ordination underlines that priestly ministry is for the whole community, which foreshadows the visible, public life of the Church.

verses.text: Moses did as the LORD commanded him, and the congregation was assembled at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
verses.comment: Moses acts in obedience, a model of how God’s commands are meant to be carried out precisely in worship and ministry.

verses.text: Moses said to the congregation, "This is the thing that the LORD has commanded to be done."
verses.comment: The gathering stresses that the priesthood is neither private nor arbitrary but instituted by divine command, anticipating the later leadership structure in the apostolic Church.

verses.text: Then Moses brought Aaron and his sons forward and washed them with water.
verses.comment: The washing symbolizes purification before entering ministry—foreshadowing Christian baptism and spiritual preparation for service.

verses.text: He put the tunic on him, tied the sash around him, clothed him with the robe, and put the ephod on him. He tied the intricately woven band of the ephod around him, binding it to him with it.
verses.comment: Aaron is clothed in sacred vestments—the tunic, robe, and ephod—all rich in symbol, signifying dignity, authority, and God’s chosen priests.

verses.text: He placed the breastplate on him, and in the breastplate he put the Urim and Thummim.
verses.comment: The breastplate was a symbol of justice and discernment, containing the Urim and Thummim, by which God’s will was sought—prefiguring spiritual guidance and authority in worship.

verses.text: He set the turban on his head, and on the turban, at the front, he placed the golden plate—the holy crown—as the LORD commanded Moses.
verses.comment: The golden plate, engraved 'Holy to the LORD,' signified consecration and holiness. Biblical priestly garments echo Christ’s role as Great High Priest (see Heb. 7:26-28).

verses.text: Then Moses took the anointing oil and anointed the tabernacle and all that was in it, consecrating them.
verses.comment: Anointing the tabernacle and its contents sanctifies them for God’s use—an act with deep sacramental resonance, pointing to anointing practices in Christian worship and leadership.

verses.text: He sprinkled some of it on the altar seven times, and anointed the altar and all its utensils, and the basin and its stand, to consecrate them.
verses.comment: Sevenfold sprinkling re-emphasizes completeness and holiness; such liturgical repetition signals the sanctity of worship space and ministry.

verses.text: He poured some of the anointing oil on Aaron’s head and anointed him, to consecrate him.
verses.comment: Aaron’s head is anointed—signifying consecration; King and priest were both anointed, foreshadowing Christ the Anointed One (Messiah means 'anointed').

verses.text: Moses brought Aaron’s sons forward, clothed them with tunics, tied sashes around them, and put caps on them, as the LORD had commanded Moses.
verses.comment: The sons of Aaron are vested, enacting their participation in the priestly ministry—marking the beginning of apostleship-like succession.

verses.text: He brought the bull of the sin offering, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the bull for the sin offering.
verses.comment: Laying hands represents identification and transfer of sin; this rite anticipates Christ’s vicarious sacrifice for sin.

verses.text: Moses slaughtered it, took the blood, and with his finger put it on the horns of the altar, purifying the altar. He poured out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar and consecrated it, making atonement for it.
verses.comment: Blood purifies and consecrates; the concept of 'atonement' finds its fullness in Christ’s blood (Heb. 9:12-14).

verses.text: Moses took all the fat that was on the entrails, the lobe of the liver, and the two kidneys with their fat, and burned it on the altar.
verses.comment: Fat portions were devoted to God; these details reinforce sacrificial completeness and God's absolute holiness.

verses.text: But the bull, its hide, its flesh, and its dung, he burned outside the camp, as the LORD commanded Moses.
verses.comment: Parts burned outside the camp anticipated Christ’s crucifixion outside Jerusalem (Heb. 13:12), a typology Protestant and historic Christianity both affirm.

verses.text: Then he presented the ram for the burnt offering, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the ram.
verses.comment: Burnt offering represents total dedication; hand-laying maintains ritual continuity—Christ offered Himself wholly for our salvation.

verses.text: Moses slaughtered it and splashed the blood against all sides of the altar.
verses.comment: Blood on the altar highlights the principle that life is given for atonement—fulfilled in Christ’s sacrifice.

verses.text: He cut the ram into pieces, and Moses burned the head, the pieces, and the fat.
verses.comment: The offering was prepared according to tradition, signifying order in worship—a model for liturgical structure.

verses.text: He washed the entrails and the legs with water, and burned the entire ram on the altar. It was a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma, an offering by fire to the LORD, as He commanded Moses.
verses.comment: 'A pleasing aroma' is language echoed for Christ’s passion (Eph. 5:2)—the fullness of sacrificial surrender.

verses.text: He brought the second ram—the ram of ordination—and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on its head.
verses.comment: Second ram was for ordination, symbolizing the passing on of ministerial authority through ritual gesture—a precursor to apostolic succession.

verses.text: Moses slaughtered it, took some of its blood, and put it on Aaron’s right ear lobe, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot.
verses.comment: Blood is placed to sanctify hearing, service, and walk—teaching that service to God is holistic, not piecemeal.

verses.text: Moses also put the blood on the right ear lobes, right thumbs, and big toes of Aaron’s sons. Then he splashed the blood against all sides of the altar.
verses.comment: Aaron's sons receive similar sanctification—the completeness of consecration is emphasized.

verses.text: He took the fat—the fat tail, all the fat on the entrails, the lobe of the liver, the two kidneys with their fat—and the right thigh.
verses.comment: Comprehensive selection of offerings—no partiality. This ordinational rite mirrors future Eucharistic unity in later Christian practice.

verses.text: From the basket of unleavened bread before the LORD, he took one unleavened cake, one cake of oiled bread, and one wafer, and put them on the fat parts and on the right thigh.
verses.comment: Bread offerings with oil signify provision, thanksgiving, and the role of sanctified food; unleavened bread prefigures later spiritual realities.

verses.text: He put all these in the hands of Aaron and his sons, and waved them as a wave offering before the LORD.
verses.comment: The wave offering dedicates everything to God. This communal ritual accentuates unity and consecration—mirrored in corporate Christian worship.

verses.text: Moses took them from their hands and burned them on the altar with the burnt offering. They were an ordination offering, a pleasing aroma, a food offering by fire to the LORD.
verses.comment: Ordination offering—'pleasing aroma'—reiterates that ministry is sacrificial, with spiritual and literal implications for later priestly actions.

verses.text: Moses took the breast and waved it as a wave offering before the LORD. It was Moses's share of the ordination ram, as the LORD commanded Moses.
verses.comment: The breast, as a wave offering, highlights designated portions for ministers, hinting at scriptural foundations for clergy support in the faith community.

verses.text: Then Moses took some of the anointing oil and some of the blood that was on the altar and sprinkled them on Aaron, his garments, Aaron’s sons and their garments. He consecrated Aaron, his garments, and his sons and their garments together.
verses.comment: Blood and oil, together, reveal the deep spiritual symbolism in consecration—combining forgiveness, cleansing, and anointing, echoes in baptism and ordination rites.

verses.text: Moses said to Aaron and his sons, "Boil the flesh at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, and eat it there with the bread from the ordination basket, as I commanded, saying, ‘Aaron and his sons shall eat it.’"
verses.comment: Priests participating in the holy meal prefigures sacred eating practices in Christian tradition; eating in God's presence is a sign of fellowship and covenant.

verses.text: Whatever is left of the flesh and the bread, you shall burn with fire.
verses.comment: All leftovers are to be burned, preventing profanation; this strict regulation points to the sacredness of sacramental food use.

verses.text: You shall not go outside the entrance of the Tent of Meeting for seven days, until the days of your ordination are completed, for it will take seven days to ordain you.
verses.comment: Seven-day ordination period stresses the significance of spiritual preparation. Extended retreat reflects importance of formation and readiness for ministry.

verses.text: "As has been done today, the LORD has commanded to be done to make atonement for you."
verses.comment: The ordination ritual was commanded for atonement, reinforcing divine initiative and the need for a priestly mediator.

verses.text: "At the entrance of the Tent of Meeting you shall remain day and night for seven days, keeping the charge of the LORD, so that you do not die; for so I have been commanded."
verses.comment: Strict observance of God’s words is a matter of life and death—accentuates the seriousness of ministerial duties and fidelity.

verses.text: And Aaron and his sons did all the things that the LORD commanded by Moses.
verses.comment: Their obedience completes the priestly ordination, a model for future ministry in the visible Church, safeguarding God’s presence and blessing among His people.
